title: Indian shares rise ahead of inflation data; Infosys drops
text:
© Reuters. Indian shares rise ahead of inflation data; Infosys drops

* NSE index up 0.27%, BSE index rises 0.24%

* Poll shows Sept retail inflation reached a 12-month high

* Infosys drops 3.44%

BENGALURU, Oct 14 (Reuters) - Indian shares edged higher on Monday ahead of the release of key inflation data, while broader Asian peers rose on optimism from the positive tone of the Sino-U.S. trade talks.

The broader NSE index rose 0.27% at 11,336.70 as of 0415 GMT, while the benchmark BSE index was up 0.24% at 38,211.46.

Indian retail inflation probably reached a 12-month high in September, but still leaving room for further interest rate cuts because it's expected to remain below the Reserve Bank of India's target, according to a Reuters poll. India's industrial output shrank at its fastest rate in more than six years in August, reflecting the impact of an economic slowdown. growth has been plagued by a drop in demand and flooding due to above-normal monsoon, Barclays (LON: ) analyst Rahul Bajoria said, but indicated that there could be a bounce back in the second half of the year.

"The case remains strong for further support to aggregate demand, and the household sector in particular," Bajoria wrote in a note.

Metal stocks led gains as the Nifty metals rose about 1.1% as commodity prices rose due to the progress in the Sino-U.S. trade talks.

Meanwhile, IT shares fell as India's No. 2 software exporter Infosys Ltd (NS: ) reported a September-quarter profit that could only meet expectations on Friday, signalling a tricky macroeconomic environment for the sector

Infosys results came after a below-par showing from larger rival Tata Consultancy Services a day earlier. shares fell 3.44%, dragging the Nifty IT index 1%.

Meanwhile, broader Asian peers rose as U.S. President Donald Trump outlined the first phase of a deal to end a trade war with China and suspended a threatened tariff hike, though officials on both sides said much more work needed to be done. MKTS/GLOB

MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan edged up 0.5%.
